articles.headline: Senators Reach Deal on Stimulus Plan as Jobs Vanish
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats reached an agreement with Republican moderates to pare the huge bill after two days of tense negotiations.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats reached an agreement with Republican moderates to pare the huge bill after two days of tense negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats reached an agreement with Republican moderates on Friday to pare a huge economic recovery measure, clearing the way for approval of a package that President Obama said was urgently needed in light of mounting job losses.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug From Gene-Altered Goats
articles.snippet: The drug, which prevents blood clots in people with a rare condition, is made from the milk of genetically engineered animals, which may usher a new era in pharmaceuticals.
articles.abstract: The drug, which prevents blood clots in people with a rare condition, is made from the milk of genetically engineered animals, which may usher a new era in pharmaceuticals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Opening the barn door to a new era in farming and pharmaceuticals, the Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first drug produced by livestock that have been given a human gene.

articles.headline: Fallout Widens as Buyers Shun Peanut Butter
articles.snippet: The drop in peanut butter sales is so striking, brands are buying ads saying that their items are not affected.
articles.abstract: The drop in peanut butter sales is so striking, brands are buying ads saying that their items are not affected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many consumers, apparently disregarding the fine print of the salmonella outbreak and food recall caused by a Georgia peanut plant, are swearing off all brands of peanut butter, driving down sales by nearly 25 percent.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Liz Robbins

articles.headline: U.S. Aided a Failed Plan to Rout Ugandan Rebels
articles.snippet: The U.S. helped coordinate an attack on a Ugandan rebel group that went awry, killing as many as 900 civilians.
articles.abstract: The U.S. helped coordinate an attack on a Ugandan rebel group that went awry, killing as many as 900 civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUNGU, Congo — The American military helped plan and pay for a recent attack on a notorious Ugandan rebel group, but the offensive went awry, scattering fighters who carried out a wave of massacres as they fled, killing as many as 900 civilians.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Nutritional Insights on Saving Money
articles.snippet: The advice of diet experts could whip your finances into shape and make self-control feel less like deprivation.
articles.abstract: The advice of diet experts could whip your finances into shape and make self-control feel less like deprivation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tired of advice from finger-wagging financial experts? You’ve come to the right place, because this week I’m turning to diet and nutrition gurus for advice on your money instead.

articles.headline: Dow Imperiled by Its Deal for Rohm & Haas
articles.snippet: Maybe, just maybe, deals that stop making sense ought to be called off.
articles.abstract: Maybe, just maybe, deals that stop making sense ought to be called off.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, the Dow Chemical Company won a heated auction for a well-run, highly valued specialty chemical company called Rohm & Haas. In agreeing to acquire this Philadelphia-based company, Dow beat out its chief rival in the chemical industry, BASF of Germany. The price it agreed to pay was high: $78 a share in cash, a 74 percent premium, for a total of about $15.3 billion.

articles.headline: Not Everyone Is Cheering as Wi-Fi Takes to the Air
articles.snippet: Wireless Internet service on airlines may become a new source of tension between passengers on packed planes.
articles.abstract: Wireless Internet service on airlines may become a new source of tension between passengers on packed planes.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the annoyance of being crammed into an aluminum tube at 35,000 feet with a bunch of strangers, air travel has offered one benefit: the ability to tell bosses and colleagues, “I’ll be on a flight, so you won’t be able to reach me.”

articles.headline: Sam Zell’s Empire, Underwater in a Big Way
articles.snippet: Few deals better exemplify the excesses of the real estate boom than the Equity Office empire’s dismemberment.
articles.abstract: Few deals better exemplify the excesses of the real estate boom than the Equity Office empire’s dismemberment.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was, for a brief shining moment, the real estate deal of the century.

articles.headline: New Plan to Help Banks Sell Bad Assets
articles.snippet: The new rescue plan, to be outlined Monday, would inject billions of dollars in fresh capital into banks and entice investors to buy their most troubled assets.
articles.abstract: The new rescue plan, to be outlined Monday, would inject billions of dollars in fresh capital into banks and entice investors to buy their most troubled assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After weeks of internal debate, the Obama administration has settled on a plan to inject billions of dollars in fresh capital into banks and entice investors to purchase their most troubled assets.

articles.headline: Back on World Stage, a Larger-Than-Life Holbrooke
articles.snippet: As special representative to Afghanistan and Pakistan, Richard C. Holbrooke will formulate policy for the region.
articles.abstract: As special representative to Afghanistan and Pakistan, Richard C. Holbrooke will formulate policy for the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stashed in a drawer in his Manhattan apartment between snapshots of family vacations, a photograph shows Richard C. Holbrooke on a private visit to Afghanistan in 2006. He is mugging atop an abandoned Russian tank, flashing a sardonic V-for-victory sign and his best Nixon-style grin. The pose is a little like Mr. Holbrooke himself: looming, theatrical, passionate, indignant.

articles.headline: In Florida, Despair and Foreclosures
articles.snippet: In Lehigh Acres, Fla., a sprawling exurb reshaped by the housing boom, the American dream is in high reverse.
articles.abstract: In Lehigh Acres, Fla., a sprawling exurb reshaped by the housing boom, the American dream is in high reverse.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEHIGH ACRES, Fla. — Desperation has moved into this once-middle-class exurb of Fort Myers, where hammers used to pound.

articles.headline: Divisions Over the Competing Stimulus Bills
articles.snippet: The House version of the stimulus bill emphasizes helping states and localities avoid wide-scale cuts, while the Senate plan focuses more on tax cuts.
articles.abstract: The House version of the stimulus bill emphasizes helping states and localities avoid wide-scale cuts, while the Senate plan focuses more on tax cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate agreement on a roughly $827 billion economic stimulus bill sets up tough negotiations with the House, primarily over tens of billions of dollars in aid to states and local governments, tax provisions, and education, health and renewable energy programs.

articles.headline: For Bank of America and Merrill, Love Was Blind
articles.snippet: It didn’t take long for Merrill Lynch and Bank of America to agree to merge. The honeymoon didn’t last long either.
articles.abstract: It didn’t take long for Merrill Lynch and Bank of America to agree to merge. The honeymoon didn’t last long either.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN mid-September, as Wall Street unwound and venerable financial institutions were brought to their knees, the mood inside the Manhattan law offices of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz was decidedly celebratory.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Bailout Needs Some Strings Attached to Limit Pay
articles.snippet: Some ideas for how to hold taxpayer-supported executives accountable for their actions, both past and future.
articles.abstract: Some ideas for how to hold taxpayer-supported executives accountable for their actions, both past and future.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST in case you missed it: The Congressional Oversight Panel monitoring the Treasury Department’s bailout of broken banks  the Troubled Asset Relief Program  reported last week that Henry M. Paulson Jr.’s team at Treasury paid significantly more for the assets it bought from banks than they were worth when the deal was announced in the fall.

articles.headline: DreamWorks Aims to Charm Reluctant Investors
articles.snippet: The tiny studio is growing at a time when bigger is not viewed as better, creating a tough balancing act.
articles.abstract: The tiny studio is growing at a time when bigger is not viewed as better, creating a tough balancing act.
articles.lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Calif.

articles.headline: Leader of Afghanistan Finds Himself Hero No More
articles.snippet: Once supported by the U.S., President Hamid Karzai is no longer in favor with the White House or his own people.
articles.abstract: Once supported by the U.S., President Hamid Karzai is no longer in favor with the White House or his own people.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  A foretaste of what would be in store for President Hamid Karzai after the election of a new American administration came last February, when Joseph R. Biden Jr., then a senator, sat down to a formal dinner at the palace during a visit here.

articles.headline: Mapping a Global Plan for Car Charging Stations
articles.snippet: Shai Agassi, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, is mapping a global plan for car charging stations where batteries can be swapped.
articles.abstract: Shai Agassi, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, is mapping a global plan for car charging stations where batteries can be swapped.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Years ago, when Shai Agassi started promoting his idea of service stations to recharge electric cars, the automotive world barely took notice.

articles.headline: Effort to Track Sex Offenders Draws Resistance
articles.snippet: Some states have objected to a federal program targeting sex offenders, saying their own laws are more effective.
articles.abstract: Some states have objected to a federal program targeting sex offenders, saying their own laws are more effective.
articles.lead_paragraph: An aggressive federal effort to keep track of sexual offenders is at risk of collapse because of objections from states and legal challenges from sex offenders and others.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Monica Davey

articles.headline: A Hard-Liner Gains Ground in Israel
articles.snippet: Avigdor Lieberman is running for prime minister on a vow to require Arab citizens to sign an oath of loyalty.
articles.abstract: Avigdor Lieberman is running for prime minister on a vow to require Arab citizens to sign an oath of loyalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Last year, he suggested publicly that Egypt’s president “go to hell.” In the Israeli parliamentary elections, to be held Tuesday, he is running on a vow to require Arab citizens to sign a loyalty oath. As his campaign slogan asserts with a sly wink at Jewish voters, Avigdor Lieberman “knows how to speak Arabic.”

articles.headline: Peanut Case Shows Holes in Safety Net
articles.snippet: Conditions at the Peanut Corporation of America were just one element in the outbreak of salmonella.
articles.abstract: Conditions at the Peanut Corporation of America were just one element in the outbreak of salmonella.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLAKELY, Ga.  Raw peanuts were stored next to the finished peanut butter. The roaster was not calibrated to kill deadly germs. Dispirited workers on minimum wage, supplied by temp agencies, donned their uniforms at home, potentially dragging contaminants into the plant, which also had rodents.

articles.headline: Business Trip, or Just a Junket? It Matters Lately
articles.snippet: With outrage over lavish events at bailed-out banks, the taint of being seen as wasteful during hard times is affecting corporate America in general.
articles.abstract: With outrage over lavish events at bailed-out banks, the taint of being seen as wasteful during hard times is affecting corporate America in general.
articles.lead_paragraph: What’s the difference between a business event and a party?
articles.byline: By Leslie Wayne and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Big Music vs. Fans and Artists
articles.snippet: Let’s take two behemoths in the live music business, smush them together, and see how that works out for the consumer.
articles.abstract: Let’s take two behemoths in the live music business, smush them together, and see how that works out for the consumer.
articles.lead_paragraph: It appears that Live Nation and Ticketmaster Entertainment are about to attempt a merger. Gee, what a great idea: Let’s take two behemoths with an overwhelming footprint in the live music business, smush them together, and see how that works out for the consumer.

articles.headline: U.S. Bank Bailout to Rely in Part on Private Money
articles.snippet: Administration officials said the new bailout was likely to depend on private investors to purchase the toxic assets that wiped out the capital of many banks.
articles.abstract: Administration officials said the new bailout was likely to depend on private investors to purchase the toxic assets that wiped out the capital of many banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street helped produce the global financial and economic crisis. Now, as the Obama administration prepares to unveil a revised bailout plan for the banking system, policy makers hope Wall Street can be part of the solution.

articles.headline: Already Back on the Trail, Now to Sell a Stimulus Plan
articles.snippet: President Obama will travel this week in an effort to build support for his economic stimulus plan.
articles.abstract: President Obama will travel this week in an effort to build support for his economic stimulus plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The presidential campaign trail often loved Barack Obama more than he loved it back. When he was sworn in last month, he told friends he was eager to tackle the rigors of the Oval Office without the drudgery of shuttling to a different part of the country every other day.

articles.headline: Resilient Strategy for Times Despite Toll of a Recession
articles.snippet: Newspaper industry analysts say that despite some published alarms to the contrary, The New York Times Company has positioned itself well to ride out another year of recession.
articles.abstract: Newspaper industry analysts say that despite some published alarms to the contrary, The New York Times Company has positioned itself well to ride out another year of recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a conference call with analysts late last month, Janet L. Robinson, the president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, laid out a vision of how the company would survive the downturn that is crippling the newspaper industry.

articles.headline: New Deal Architecture Faces Bulldozer
articles.snippet: A movement hopes to save from demolition hundreds of buildings built by the Works Progress Administration.
articles.abstract: A movement hopes to save from demolition hundreds of buildings built by the Works Progress Administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENHILLS, Ohio  When people talk about green architecture as though it were a new movement, Greg Strupe laughs. Mr. Strupe lives with his family in one of the country’s first green towns, built during the Great Depression by unemployed men and women and championed by Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt.

articles.headline: Why Analysts Keep Telling Investors to Buy
articles.snippet: Analysts’ buy ratings seem to reflect a hope that the market will soon turn a corner. Why should investors believe them this time?
articles.abstract: Analysts’ buy ratings seem to reflect a hope that the market will soon turn a corner. Why should investors believe them this time?
articles.lead_paragraph: Even now, with the recession deepening and markets on edge, Wall Street analysts say it is a good time to buy.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Michael M. Grynbaum
